courses.title: Introduction to Physics
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of motion, forces, and energy.

subtopics.title: Speed
subtopics.content:
Speed is the distance travelled per unit time.

It is a scalar quantity, meaning it has magnitude but no direction. Speed tells us how fast an object is moving.

subtopics.title: Velocity
subtopics.content:
Velocity is the rate of change of displacement with respect to time.

Unlike speed, velocity is a vector quantity and includes both magnitude and direction.

subtopics.title: Acceleration
subtopics.content:
Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time.

It can be calculated using the formula:

a = (v₂ - v₁) / t

Acceleration can be positive, negative, or zero depending on the motion.

subtopics.title: Force
subtopics.content:
A force is a push or a pull that can change the motion or shape of an object.

Forces can cause objects to accelerate, slow down, stop, or change direction.

subtopics.title: Newton’s First Law
subtopics.content:
Newton’s First Law states that an object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force.

This law is also known as the law of inertia.

subtopics.title: Newton’s Second Law
subtopics.content:
Newton’s Second Law states that the acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass.

It is commonly expressed as:

F = ma

subtopics.title: Work
subtopics.content:
Work is said to be done when a force causes a displacement of an object.

Mathematically, work is defined as the product of force and displacement in the direction of the force.

subtopics.title: Kinetic Energy
subtopics.content:
Kinetic energy is the energy possessed by an object due to its motion.

It depends on the mass and the square of the velocity of the object.

subtopics.title: Potential Energy
subtopics.content:
Potential energy is the energy stored in an object due to its position or configuration.

Gravitational potential energy depends on height and mass.

courses.title: Basic Mathematics for Problem Solving
courses.description: Core mathematical concepts used in science and everyday problem solving.

subtopics.title: Variables and Expressions
subtopics.content:
Variables are symbols used to represent unknown values.

Algebraic expressions combine variables, numbers, and operations to describe mathematical relationships.

subtopics.title: Linear Equations
subtopics.content:
A linear equation is an equation in which the highest power of the variable is one.

Linear equations often represent straight-line relationships.

subtopics.title: Quadratic Equations
subtopics.content:
Quadratic equations are equations of degree two.

They are commonly written in the form ax² + bx + c = 0 and can have one or two real solutions.

subtopics.title: What is a Function?
subtopics.content:
A function is a relationship that assigns exactly one output to each input.

Functions are commonly used to model real-world relationships.

subtopics.title: Graph of a Function
subtopics.content:
The graph of a function visually represents the relationship between inputs and outputs.

Graphs help in understanding trends and rates of change.

subtopics.title: Rate of Change
subtopics.content:
The rate of change describes how one quantity changes with respect to another.

In physics, acceleration is an example of rate of change of velocity.

subtopics.title: Limits
subtopics.content:
A limit describes the value that a function approaches as the input approaches a certain value.

Limits are the foundation of calculus.

subtopics.title: Derivatives
subtopics.content:
A derivative represents the rate of change of a function.

Derivatives are used to calculate velocity, acceleration, and slopes of curves.

subtopics.title: Real-World Examples
subtopics.content:
Calculus concepts are used to model motion, growth, and change in real-world systems.

They are widely applied in physics, engineering, and economics.

courses.title: Introduction to Computer Science
courses.description: Foundational concepts of programming, algorithms, and data structures.

subtopics.title: What is a Program?
subtopics.content:
A program is a set of instructions that tells a computer what to do.

Programs are written to solve problems or automate tasks.

subtopics.title: Variables and Data Types
subtopics.content:
Variables store data values, and data types define the kind of data a variable can hold.

Common data types include integers, strings, and booleans.

subtopics.title: Control Flow
subtopics.content:
Control flow determines the order in which instructions are executed.

Examples include conditional statements and loops.

subtopics.title: What is an Algorithm?
subtopics.content:
An algorithm is a step-by-step procedure for solving a problem.

Algorithms must be clear, finite, and effective.

subtopics.title: Time Complexity
subtopics.content:
Time complexity measures how the runtime of an algorithm grows with input size.

It helps compare the efficiency of different algorithms.

subtopics.title: Searching vs Sorting
subtopics.content:
Searching algorithms are used to find elements, while sorting algorithms arrange data.

Both are fundamental to efficient problem solving.

subtopics.title: Arrays
subtopics.content:
Arrays store elements in contiguous memory locations.

They allow fast access using an index.

subtopics.title: Lists
subtopics.content:
Lists store ordered collections of elements.

They allow dynamic resizing and sequential access.

subtopics.title: Stacks
subtopics.content:
A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last In, First Out principle.

Common operations include push and pop.
